Because prompting “award-winning concept art” isn’t the same as making it.

P.S.: You may want to grab a coffee or something stronger before diving into what almost turned into a book (apologies for that!). Grab your compass. We’re heading straight into terra incognita.

Hype vs. Reality

AI image generation has been living its best life in the headlines lately. You've probably noticed if you’ve been anywhere near the internet recently. Every other day, there’s a new “revolutionary” tool, “mind-blowing” upgrade, or “game-changing” feature promising to redefine creativity as we know it. Amazing, right? Except that’s the polished version. The demos are cinematic, the Twitter threads are euphoric. Let’s not confuse the highlight reel with the actual tool, though.

Most of these announcements are the tech world’s version of a movie trailer. All sparkle, no plot. Cool tech? Yes. A replacement for deeper understanding? Absolutely not.

All of this is very exciting. In theory.

But it’s all fun and games until you actually need these tools to work consistently and exactly as instructed. Like, say, creating a comic where the same character needs to appear in multiple panels, poses, and moods without morphing into a stranger every time. That’s when the so-called “revolution” starts to feel like a glitchy battlefield. Every variation becomes a roll of the dice, and consistency turns into a nerve-wracking nightmare.

I’m rooting for these tools, I really am (better be kind to the AI, right?). But here’s the thing. There is a big difference between using AI to create something cool in seconds just for fun, versus actually relying on it to meet a specific creative goal.
